title: 114_hr6314
content: The Act is titled the "Commission on the Removal of Mexican-Americans to Mexico Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. Congress found that from 1929 to 1941, there was a program to forcibly remove 1.2 million individuals of Mexican ancestry, including US citizens, to Mexico due to public pressure to reduce Mexican-American employment during the Depression. Massive raids were conducted on these communities. The Act aims to establish a commission to investigate the forced removal of US citizens and legal residents of Mexican ancestry to Mexico from 1929 to 1941, which deprived them of their rights and livelihoods. No official inquiry has been conducted into these raids. The Act aims to establish a commission to investigate the forced removal of US citizens and legal residents of Mexican ancestry to Mexico from 1929 to 1941, impacting individuals, families, and the Mexican-American community in the United States. Establishment of a commission named the "Commission on the Removal of Mexican-Americans to Mexico" to review the forced removal of US citizens and legal residents of Mexican ancestry to Mexico from 1929 to 1941. The commission will also examine past government directives related to these removals and submit a report with findings and recommendations to Congress. The Commission on the Removal of Mexican-Americans to Mexico will consist of seven members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate. Members must have expertise in human rights, civil rights, immigration, labor, or business. Each member serves for life, with a quorum of four members required for meetings. Members must have expertise in human rights, civil rights, immigration, labor, or business. Each member serves for life, with a quorum of four members required for meetings. The initial meeting of the Commission shall be called by the President within one hundred and twenty days after the date of the enactment of this Act, or within thirty days after the date on which legislation is enacted making appropriations to carry out this Act, whichever is later. The Commission shall elect a chairperson and vice chairperson from among its members, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission, or any subcommittee or member authorized by the Commission, can hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Public hearings can be held in any U.S. city deemed appropriate. The Commission has the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations under the Act. Failure to comply with a subpoena may result in consequences. The Commission can apply to a court for an order to compel a person to testify or produce evidence related to an investigation. Failure to comply may result in civil contempt. Subpoenas issued by the Commission must be served according to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The Commission can obtain official data from government agencies and may contract with agencies or individuals for services necessary to carry out its duties under the Act. SEC. 7. STAFF. The Commission has the authority to appoint additional staff, including experts and consultants, and may receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. Staff appointments are not bound by certain civil service laws. The Commission is required to submit a report to Congress within one year of its initial meeting, detailing its findings, conclusions, and legislative recommendations. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. The Commission refers to the Commission on the Removal of Mexican-Americans to Mexico established under section 3. A member is an individual on the Commission. State includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories.
